prior_works.title: 3D Gaussian Splatting for Real-Time Radiance Field Rendering
prior_works.authors: Thomas Kerbl, Georgios Kopanas, Thomas Leimkühler, George Drettakis
prior_works.relationship_sentence: GIC builds directly on 3D Gaussian Splatting by using the Gaussian parameterization and its efficient, differentiable rasterizer to both recover geometry from images and render masks during simulation, enabling geometry-aware supervision and infusion of Gaussian attributes into the continuum.

prior_works.title: NeRF: Representing Scenes as Neural Radiance Fields for View Synthesis
prior_works.authors: Ben Mildenhall, Pratul P. Srinivasan, Matthew Tancik, Jonathan T. Barron, Ravi Ramamoorthi, Ren Ng
prior_works.role: Foundational differentiable volumetric rendering for geometry-from-images
prior_works.relationship_sentence: NeRF established the paradigm of optimizing 3D structure and appearance from multi-view images via differentiable rendering, a principle GIC retains while replacing implicit fields with explicit Gaussians to better interface with continuum simulation and mask-based supervision.

prior_works.title: D-NeRF: Neural Radiance Fields for Dynamic Scenes
prior_works.authors: Albert Pumarola, Enric Corona, Gerard Pons-Moll, Francesc Moreno-Noguer
prior_works.relationship_sentence: GIC’s dynamic 3D Gaussian framework adopts a motion factorization strategy reminiscent of D-NeRF’s canonical-space deformation, enabling consistent reconstruction of time-varying geometry as Gaussian point sets across states.

prior_works.title: ChainQueen: A Real-Time Differentiable Physical Simulator for Soft Robotics
prior_works.authors: Huamin Hu, He Wang, Roberto Martin-Martin, Zhenjia Xu, Dequan Wang, Li Fei-Fei, Jiajun Wu
prior_works.role: Differentiable continuum mechanics for system identification
prior_works.relationship_sentence: ChainQueen showed that differentiable continuum simulation enables visual system identification of material properties; GIC leverages this insight by constructing a Gaussian-informed continuum whose parameters can be optimized from rendered visual signals.

prior_works.title: DiffTaichi: Differentiable Programming for Physical Simulation

prior_works.role: Practical framework for differentiable physics and parameter estimation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: GIC’s training loop—backpropagating from image-space objectives to physical parameters—follows the differentiable-programming paradigm popularized by DiffTaichi, enabling efficient gradient-based system identification.

prior_works.relationship_sentence: GIC’s coarse-to-fine filling strategy that converts Gaussian reconstructions into volumetric density fields and extractable surfaces echoes classic Poisson-style reconstruction principles of aggregating local kernels into smooth, watertight geometry.

prior_works.title: Soft Rasterizer: A Differentiable Renderer for Image-based 3D Reasoning
prior_works.authors: Shichen Liu, Weikai Chen, Tianye Li, Hao Li
prior_works.relationship_sentence: GIC’s use of rendered object masks as 2D shape surrogates during simulation is inspired by silhouette-based differentiable rendering from SoftRas, adapted to the Gaussian rasterization domain for stable, geometry-aware supervision.

synthesis_narrative:
GIC’s core contribution—coupling a dynamic 3D Gaussian representation with continuum simulation for visual system identification—sits at the intersection of differentiable rendering, dynamic scene modeling, and differentiable physics. At its foundation, 3D Gaussian Splatting provides an explicit, attribute-rich representation and efficient differentiable rasterizer, which GIC repurposes to both reconstruct geometry and render supervision masks during simulation. Building on the differentiable volumetric rendering paradigm established by NeRF, GIC preserves image-driven optimization but replaces implicit fields with Gaussians to better bridge to physical continuums.
Dynamic reconstruction in GIC relies on motion factorization, conceptually aligned with D-NeRF’s canonical-space warping, enabling temporally consistent Gaussian point sets across states. On the physics side, ChainQueen demonstrated that differentiable continuum mechanics can recover material parameters from visual signals, and DiffTaichi codified the practical training loop for gradient-based system identification—both directly informing GIC’s end-to-end optimization from rendered objectives to physical properties.
To translate discrete Gaussians into simulatable bodies, GIC introduces a coarse-to-fine filling that yields volumetric density fields and extractable surfaces, echoing Poisson reconstruction’s aggregation of local kernels into smooth geometry. Finally, GIC’s use of mask rendering as a 2D shape surrogate during simulation is a Gaussian-native realization of silhouette-based supervision popularized by SoftRas. Together, these works enable GIC’s Gaussian-informed continuum to bring geometry-aware guidance into visual system identification and physics-consistent simulation.
